items.content: Check the section, read only the paragraph names.

content.body:
Give the title of this section:

Willam of and II

prompt.body: Which subquestion you should be able to answer after reading the text?

content.body: How did criticism of the Roman-Catholic Church led to the Reformation and to the split in the Christian church?
What caused all unrest in the Low Countries?
How did the unrest in the Low Countries lead to the Revolt?
What caused the final break between Philip II and William of Orange?
How did the Revolt lay the foundations for the Dutch state?

prompt.body: Put the names of the paragraphs in the right order.

content.body: William of Orange takes a stand

prompt.body: Put the next governors, or: the deputy of the sovereign ruler, in the right order.

content.body: Philips II wars all over Europa had Spain, leaving no money to pay the Spanish soldiers. And after the death of Requesens there was not even a to preserve discipline. Mutiny broke out among the army and during the they sacked numerous towns, like Antwerp. Therefore all the provinces came together in the and banded together to drive the Spanish forces out of the Low Countries. In an official document, the , they promised to work together. Religious problems would be solved later, the compromise was that Holland and Zeeland remained and the other provinces . However, the Pacification had little effect. The Spanish troops withdrew to reorganise, but seized control over cities. In the city of Amsterdam for example, the protestant Seabaggers forced the catholic citycouncil and clergy to leave. The growing lack of trust in the protestants drove a few Walloon and Catholic provinces to make peace with Philip II, the . As a reaction the protestant provinces renewed their pledges in the in the same year: 1579.

questions.label: (Words) Spanish Fury and the Union of Utrecht

prompt.body: Put the next events in the right order.

content.body: Growing unrest in the Spanish army

prompt.body:
Honoured wise men and governors of the city of Brouwershaven. We hereby inform you that we wish to come to you with our ships early tomorrow morning, and give you our assurance that we intend no injury whatsoever to your governors or citizens. Our aim is to destroy the idolatry that forced us to abandon our possessions. We are hunting for papists, monks and other Roman Catholic evil-doers. If any people wish to leave the city, we promise that we will not harm even one hair on their heads, but will escort and help them. Should you resist us, however, then we will take you as prisoners and set fire to everything within our reach.

Note: Papist was a term of abuse for Roman Catholics.

Read the source. Based on this source, you could conclude that the Revolt against Philip II was both a religious war and a civil war. Which conclusions are correct? Choose the two best answers.

content.body: The source shows that the Revolt was a religious war, because the Sea Beggars intend to kill all the Catholics in the city.
You can conclude from the source that the Revolt was a religious war, because the Sea Beggars want to destroy the Catholic churches.
You can conclude from the source that the Revolt was a religious war, because the Catholics and the Protestants are in conflict.
The source shows that the Revolt was a civil war, because it describes the recapture of the Dutch city of Brouwershaven by the Sea Beggars.
The source describes the war between Catholic and Protestant citizens.
The source shows how the Catholics were driven off by the Protestants.

prompt.body:
First lines of the 'Wilhelmus', the national anthem which was written around 1570.

1 Wilhelmus van Nassouwe ben ik, van Duitsen bloed,
2 den vaderland getrouwe blijf ik tot in den dood.
3 Een Prinse van Oranje ben ik, vrij onverveerd,
4 den Koning van Hispanje heb ik altijd geëerd.

Which line is about the offspring William of Orange?

First lines of the 'Wilhelmus'

1 Wilhelmus van Nassouwe ben ik, van Duitsen bloed,
2 den vaderland getrouwe blijf ik tot in den dood.
3 Een Prinse van Oranje ben ik, vrij onverveerd,
4 den Koning van Hispanje heb ik altijd geëerd.

Which line is about William of Orange loyalty to the Dutch Revolt?

First lines of the 'Wilhelmus'

1 Wilhelmus van Nassouwe ben ik, van Duitsen bloed,
2 den vaderland getrouwe blijf ik tot in den dood.
3 Een Prinse van Oranje ben ik, vrij onverveerd,
4 den Koning van Hispanje heb ik altijd geëerd.

Which line is about William of Orange loyalty to Philip II?

Sixth part of the Wilhelmus

1 Mijn schild ende betrouwen zijt Gij, o God mijn Heer,
2 op U zo wil ik bouwen, Verlaat mij nimmermeer.
3 Dat ik toch vroom mag blijven, uw dienaar t'aller stond,
4 de tirannie verdrijven die mij mijn hart doorwondt.

Which line does not match with William's loyalty to Philip II?

Last lines of the Wilhelmus:

1 Voor God wil ik belijden en zijner groten macht,
2 dat ik tot genen tijden den Koning heb veracht,
3 dan dat ik God den Heere, der hoogsten Majesteit,
4 heb moeten obediëren in der gerechtigheid.

Which lines tells you that William didn't had bad feelings about Philip II?

You know, My Lords, by whom and why the religious practises, which they call heresy, were introduced. Though they asked at the time for my advice, I never made any recommendations and left that decision entirely up to the duchess of Parma. As later developments would prove, I was wrong to do this. However, God has show that He will not allow the king's and the duchess's perjury to go unpunished. Thus, God has made it clear to one and all that He will indeed punish those who abuse His Name. You know only all too well that the Iconoclasm was in no way pleasing to me. And you also know that many have blamed me for never having been willing to approve such practices where the magistrates had not granted their permission.

Read the source. What is William of Orange's position on the religion?

content.body: He sides with the Catholics, because he calls the Protestants heretics.
He sides with the Catholics, because is opposed to the Iconoclasm.
He sides with the Protestants, because he opposes the perjury of the king and the duchess, who are Catholics.
He wants Protestantism to be the only religion, because he believes in God, who will punish anyone who abuses His name.
He does not say any one religion is the right one.

prompt.body:
He did this without the consent of the States, towns or provinces. Moreover, he decided to implement this measure by force. When he heard that certain brave men were revolting at the very moment that he received word of the capture of Brielle, he had already decided to murder the most distinguished citizens of Brussels under cover of night, because they had resisted the tax measure that he had imposed, in violation of the privileges of that land. Charles, their executioner, had given orders to make ready 17 gallows and ladders of three or four metres high. All the soldiers were armed and Don Frederico had gone to the home of Viglius to collect the arrest warrants, precisely at the moment that the population heard the good news about the capture of Brielle. One of them was sentenced to death, because he had refused to have executed several men who resisted the tax measure. Alba had said to him, only shortly before: "I swear to you by my beard that if you do not carry out my orders I will have you hung. No judge is to be trusted, mine are the only orders that you are to carry out."

Read the source. Which sentence best reflects the message of this source? Choose the best answer.

content.body: The population rose up in revolt against Alba, who ordered tax measures and executions that violated the towns' privileges.
The Spanish surrendered the town of Brielle to the Sea Beggars.
Alba made plans to recapture Brielle.
Alba ordered a judge to be hanged.
